column28: Instructions

column12: 12 oz. andouille sausage, sliced into 1/2 inch pieces
column28: In a large, deep skillet over medium-low heat, melt butter, then add oil and flour. Cook, stirring constantly, until dark caramel colored, about 10 minutes
column29: Add onions, peppers, and celery, and stir until softened, about 5 minutes more. Stir in garlic and sausage, then season with Cajun seasoning, salt, and pepper. Stir in bay leaf, diced tomatoes, and chicken broth and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low and simmer until thickened, stirring occasionally, about 1 hour
column30: In the last 10 minutes of cooking, add shrimp. Once shrimp is pink and cooked through, taste and adjust seasonings. Stir in green onions, reserving some for garnish
column31: Serve spooned on top of white rice

column28: Preheat grill for high heat
column29: In a large bowl, mix ground beef, egg, bread crumbs, evaporated milk, worcestershire sauce, cayenne pepper, and garlic using your hands. For the mixture into 8 hamburger patties
column30: Lightly oil the grill grate. Grill patties 5 minutes per side, or until well done
column31: Place patties onto bottom of hamburger bun
column32: Add your toppings and the top hamburger bun

column28: Preheat fry pan
column29: Combine flour, sugar, cinnamon, baking powder, and salt into a large bowl
column30: Mix together wet ingredients and beat into dry mixture until smooth
column32: Pour or spoon batter into fry pan in desired quantity
column33: Flip when top begins to bubble, then cook a minute more

column28: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F
column29: Combine flour, baking soda, and salt in small bowl. Beat butter, granulated sugar, brown sugar, and vanilla extract in large mixer bowl until creamy. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Gradually beat in flour mixture. Stir in morsels and nuts. Drop by rounded tablespoon onto ungreased baking sheets.
column30: Bake for 9 to 11 minutes or until golden brown. Cool on baking sheets for 2 minutes; remove to wire racks to cool completely.

column28: Add rice and 1/2 cup water to saucepan, cover, and place on a stove at maximum heat. When water starts boiling, turn heat down and let simmer for 15-20 minutes. Remove from heat and let steam for a further 15-20 minutes. Uncover, stir through and serve
column29: Add a little water to a small saucepan. Add miso paste and stir until smooth. Heat up liquid dashi, add miso paste mixture and stir through (you can add wakame seaweed and tofu to the miso soup)
column30: Spread shio koji on salmon fillet and let marinade for as long as possible (1-2 days is ideal). Wipe off excess shio koji and pan-fry salmon until meat flakes away easily with a fork
column31: Mix together sesame, soy sauce, sugar and a little salt to season, until the resulting seasoning resembles a thick paste. Meanwhile, steam beans until tender, strain, and run briefly under running cold water. Throw beans into sesame dressing while still warm. Stir through and serve

column28: Gently beat the eggs in a bowl then add the light soy sauce, honey, water and mix well
column29: Heat an omelette pan or small frying pan over medium heat. Add oil generously using some greased kitchen roll. Pour a thin layer of the egg mixture into the pan. Pierce any air bubbles as they appear. Cook for 1/2-1 min. Roll the omelette into a log shape. Push the omelette to the top side of the pan and grease the pan again. Pour another thin layer of egg mixture and continue rolling. Repeat this process until the egg mixture is finished
column31: Place the omelette on a bamboo mat or cutting board and shape gently. If using a cutting board use a towel or cling film to form the omelette into a round log. Let it stand for a few minutes. Cut omelette into bite-sized pieces. Set aside
column32: Slice the sausages hallways only into four strips. Place the sausages into hot water and boil them until they float. Set aside
column33: Wet your hands and rub a pinch of sea salt on both palms to help the rice from sticking. Scoop 200g of cooked warm rice and mould into 2 even sized triangular shaped onigiri using both hands. Coat one with white sesame seeds and the other with black sesame seeds
column34: Place the last 100g cooked warm rice in a bowl and mix with the shiso flakes until evenly combined. Make another onigiri with this shiso rice mixture
column35: Carefully pack the onigiri, tamagoyaki and octopus-shaped sausages into a bento box. Enjoy for lunch or a picnic

column28: Cut nori in half (4 x 7 1/2 inches)
column29: Cut tuna into long, thin sticks 1/2 inch thick and 7 1/2 inch long
column30: Put bamboo sushi mat flat on your work surface with the bamboo slats left to right, so you can roll the mat away from you
column31: Put a nori sheet on top of the bamboo mat with one of the seaweed's long sides close to the front edge of the sushi mat
column32: Spread 3/4 cup of sushi rice on top of the nori sheet
column33: Place tuna horizontally on the rice
column34: Roll up bamboo mat, pressing forward to shape the sushi into a cylinder. Roll from the front end of the mat guiding with the sushi mat toward the other end. Tighten the rolls like roll cakes, pulling mat to tighten
column35: Press the bamboo mat firmly and remove the roll from the mat
column37: Wipe a knife with a wet cloth before slicing sushi
column38: Cut rolled sushi into bite-size pieces and serve immediately

column16: 1/3 cup finely chopped shallots or red onion
column28: In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment (you can also just use a regular mixing bowl and knead by hand), dissolve the yeast in the warm water. Sift together the flour and cornstarch, and add it to the yeast mixture along with the sugar and oil. Turn on the mixer to the lowest setting and let it go until a smooth dough ball is formed. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for 2 hours. (I haven't forgotten about the baking powder. You'll add that later!)
column29: While the dough is resting, make the meat filling. Heat the oil in a wok over medium high heat. Add the onion and stir-fry for a minute. Turn heat down to medium-low, and add the sugar, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sesame oil, and dark soy. Stir and cook until the mixture starts to bubble up. Add the chicken stock and flour, cooking for a couple minutes until thickened. Remove from the heat and stir in the roast pork. Set aside to cool. If you make the filling ahead of time, cover and refrigerate to prevent it from drying out.
column30: After your dough has rested for 2 hours, add the baking powder to the dough and turn the mixer on to the lowest setting. At this point, if the dough looks dry or you're having trouble incorporating the baking powder, add 1-2 teaspoons water. Gently knead the dough until it becomes smooth again. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for another 15 minutes. In the meantime, get a large piece of parchment paper and cut it into ten 4x4 inch squares. Prepare your steamer by bringing the water to a boil.
column31: Now we are ready to assemble the buns: roll the dough into a long tube and divide it into 10 equal pieces. Press each piece of dough into a disc about 4 1/2 inches in diameter (it should be thicker in the center and thinner around the edges). Add some filling and pleat the buns until they're closed on top.
column32: Place each bun on a parchment paper square, and steam. I steamed the buns in two separate batches using a bamboo steamer (be sure the boiling water does not touch the buns during steaming process). Once the water boils, place the buns in the steamer and steam each batch for 12 minutes over high heat.

column1: Big Plate of Chicken with Noodles
column11: 2 green onion, white part only, cut into 1 inch sections
column17: 2 middle size potatoes, peeled and cut into 3-4cm chunks
column20: 1/2 red onion, cut into small pieces
column28: Cut chicken into small chunks (you can use 4 chicken thighs as a substitute to a whole chicken). Place in a large pot, add 1 green onion and 2 slices of ginger and then bring to a boiling. Cook for 1 minute, pick the chicken out and clean with warm water. Set aside and drain.
column29: Heat up 3 tablespoons of oil in wok, add garlic, ginger, white part of green onion, dried chili pepper, star anise and Sichuan peppercorn, fry over slow fire until aroma. Add doubanjiang and continue frying for 1 minute until the oil turns red.
column30: Place chicken chunks in, turn up the fire and fry until slightly browned. Add Shaoxing wine and light soy sauce. Mix well.
column31: Pour in enough water until 1cm higher than than chicken. Bring to a boiling, and cover with a lid. Simmer over slow fire. Add potato chunks after 10 minutes and then continue cooking for another 15 minutes.
column32: Turn up the fire and start to evaporate extra water. When the liquid lever is around reduced to 1/3, add red pepper, green pepper and red onion. Give everything a big stir fry to mix well.
column33: Meanwhile, cook wide noodles in another pot according to the instruction and lay the noodles in the bottle of your serving plate.
column34: Transfer the braised chicken to top the noodles and serve directly.

column5: 500g fresh ho fun noodle (if you are using dried ones, pre-soak 300g until soft)
column6: 1 pound beef brisket, cut into middle size chunks
column8: 3 green onions, whites and green part chopped separately
column28: Soak the spices with clean water for around 10 minutes. And then wrap with gauze. Seal with a rope or gauze strip. This will prevent the spices mixing with the soup.
column29: Bring a large pot of water to boil and cook the beef brisket for 2-3 minutes. Transfer the beef brisket out and rinse under running water to clean. Drain.
column30: Heat up 2 tablespoons of cooking oil, fry garlic, ginger and ginger for 1-2 minutes over slow fire or until aroma. Place beef brisket in and fry for 3-4 minutes until fragrant. Add light soy sauce and continue frying for 1 or 2 minutes. Pour enough water to pot.
column31: Place the spice gauze bag in and simmer for 2-3 minutes or transfer to high pressure cooker and cook for 30 minutes. Add salt before assembling. (Note 2)
column32: Bring water to boil and rinse ho fun noodles for 30- 40 seconds. Rinse lettuce leaves too. Transfer noodle and lettuce leaves to serving bowl.
column33: Top ho fun noodle soup bowl with beef brisket, chopped green onion and chopped coriander and scoop beef soup to cover the noodles. Serve hot!

column7: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
column8: 5 medium carrots, cut diagonally in 1-inch pieces
column9: 3 celery stalks, cut diagonally in 1-inch pieces
column13: 1/2 bottle of good dry red wine such as Burgundy
column16: 1 tbsp. unsalted butter, at room temperature, plus 1 tbsp unsalted butter, melted
column19: 1/2 lb. cremini mushrooms, stems removed and thickly sliced
column28: Preheat the oven to 300 degrees F.
column29: In a large dutch oven, cook the chopped bacon over medium heat for 8 to 10 minutes, until crispy. Remove the bacon to a large plate with a slotted spoon.
column30: Meanwhile, lay the chicken out on paper towels and pat dry. Generously sprinkle all pieces with salt and pepper. After removing the bacon, brown the chicken pieces in batches in a single layer for about 5 minutes on each side, turning to brown evenly on all sides. Remove the chicken to the plate with the bacon and continue to brown until all the chicken is done. Set aside.
column31: Add the carrots, celery, onions, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1 teaspoon pepper to the pan and cook over medium heat for 10 to 12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are lightly browned. Add the garlic and cook for 1 more minute. Add the Cognac and put the bacon, chicken, and any juices that collected on the plate into the pot. Add the wine, chicken stock, and thyme and bring to a simmer. Cover the pot with a tight fitting lid and place in the oven for 40 to 50 minutes, until the chicken is just not pink. Remove from the oven and place on top of the stove.
column32: Whisk 1 tablespoon of melted butter and the flour together and stir into the stew. Add the frozen onions. In a medium saute pan, add the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter and cook the mushrooms over medium-low heat for 5 to 10 minutes, until browned. Add to the stew. Bring the stew to a simmer and cook for another 10 minutes. Season to taste.
column33: Serve and enjoy hot with French bread or mashed potatoes!

column28: Whisk all the ingredients vigorously until the crepe batter is completely smooth; allow the batter to rest in the refrigerator for at least 20 minutes before making the crepes.
column29: Melt 1 tablespoon butter in a crepe pan or large skillet over low-medium heat.
column30: Add 3 tablespoons of batter to the pan and swirl until the bottom of the pan is covered with batter.
column31: Cook the crepe for 1 minute, or until the crepe is slightly moist on top and golden underneath.
column32: Loosen the edges of the crepe, slide the spatula under it, and then gently flip it upside down into the pan.
column33: Cook for 1 minute and transfer the cooked crepe to a plate to keep warm. Repeat the process with the remaining batter.
column34: In a large skillet set over medium heat, melt half of the butter until it foams.
column35: Remove the skillet from the heat and sprinkle the half the sugar over the melted butter.
column36: Add half the Grand Marnier, handling the skillet carefully because of the flame, and then add the crepes to the pan to coat both sides in the orange syrup.
column37: Fold the crepes into quarters or roll them into cylinders.
column38: Melt the remaining butter in the skillet, remove it from the heat, and then add the sugar and Grand Marnier to make more orange syrup.
column39: Place a scoop of ice cream next to each crepe and drizzle the crepe Suzette with the orange syrup.

column14: Unsalted butter, room temperature, for brushing
column28: Preheat oven to 450 degrees with rack in bottom third. Blanch broccoli rabe in batches in a pot of salted boiling water until just tender, about 2 minutes. Drain.
column29: Heat oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add garlic; cook, stirring, 30 seconds. Add broccoli rabe; cook, stirring, 2 minutes. Season with salt. Let cool slightly, then finely chop.
column30: For each sandwich, spread 2 teaspoons jam on one bread slice and 1 teaspoon mustard on another. Layer one slice with cheese, broccoli rabe, and ham, dividing evenly. Close sandwich; brush each side with butter.
column31: Place the sandwiches on a baking sheet, top with 2 tablespoons bechamel and 1/4 cup grated Gruyere. Broil until golden brown and bubbling, about 10 minutes.

column28: Wash the lentils in cold water until the water runs clear. Put lentils in a pot with enough water to cover; bring to a boil, place a cover on the pot, reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer, adding water during cooking as needed to keep covered, until tender, 15 to 20 minutes. Drain.
column29: Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat; cook and stir onions in hot oil until caramelized, about 20 minutes.
column30: Mix curry paste, curry powder, turmeric, cumin, chili powder, salt, sugar, garlic, and ginger together in a large bowl; stir into the onions. Increase heat to high and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes.
column31: Stir in the tomato puree, remove from heat and stir into the lentils.

column12: 1 pound skinless, boneless chicken breast-cut into 1-inch strips
column28: Combine yogurt, 2 teaspoons garam masala, paprika, black pepper, 1/2 teaspoon salt, cayenne pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon coriander in a large bowl. Add chicken strips and toss to coat. Cover and marinate in the refrigerator for 2 hours.
column29: Preheat oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet.
column30: Place chicken strips on the prepared baking sheet, leaving space between each piece, and bake in the preheated oven until browned and no longer pink inside, about 10 minutes. Remove and set aside.
column31: Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Cook and stir cumin seeds until lightly toasted and aromatic, about 3 minutes. Add onion; cook and stir until onion begins to soften, 4 to 5 minutes. Stir in garlic, ginger, and green chiles and continue to cook until onion is browned, 15 to 20 minutes. Cook and stir tomatoes, tomato paste, and water into onion mixture until tomatoes begin to break down and incorporate into the onion mixture, about 10 minutes.
column32: Cook and stir 1 teaspoon garam masala, 1/2 teaspoon coriander, and turmeric into the tomato mixture. Mix in the cooked chicken, add cream, and stir to coat. Cover and let simmer for 10 minutes. Season with 1/2 teaspoon salt and garnish with cilantro.

column28: Soak rice for minimum 3 hrs. Drain and transfer to a mixer along with grated coconut, salt.
column29: Grind very smoothly adding required water. Adjust water consistency so that it is runny like we make for rava dosa. Thinner better.
column30: Heat a tawa and pour the prepared batter first along the outside and fill in the middle. After a minute, flip cook for half more minute.

column11: Three 7-ounce cans Mexican tomato sauce (I use El Patobrand) or enchilada sauce
column13: 3/4 cup grated Cheddar, plus extra for sprinkling
column28: Preheat the oven to 170 to 180 degrees F.
column29: In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the onions until softened. Then add the ground beef and cook until the beef is cooked through. Add the cumin, chili powder, oregano and salt and stir to combine. Pour 2 cans of the Mexican tomato sauce into the meat and simmer over low heat for 5 minutes. Add a little water if the mixture gets too dry.
column31: Meanwhile, heat the refried beans in a saucepan over medium-low heat. Add the cheese, and stir it in till its melted. Remove from the heat.
column32: Heat the tortillas in the microwave for 1 minute, and then spread a small amount of beans on each tortilla. Add a small amount of the meat. Fold over the ends of the tortilla, and then roll them up. Repeat with the rest of the tortillas. Then place them in a large baking dish, cover with foil and keep warm in the oven.
column33: When ready to serve, drizzle the remaining can of tomato sauce over all of the burritos and sprinkle with more grated Cheddar. Return to the oven for a couple of minutes just to melt the cheese.
column34: Sprinkle the tops with the cilantro leaves and serve immediately to the fork-bangers in your life. They'll kiss you and hug you. Repeatedly.

column5: 1 large yellow or white onion, diced
column28: Heat a large cast iron skillet over high heat with 2 tablespoons oil. Add the onions and spices and saute until translucent and soft, about 5 minutes.
column29: Add green chilies and chorizo to the pan and stir to combine. Let the chorizo brown, about 4-5 minutes.
column30: Reduce heat to medium and add in the sweet potato and stir to combine. Pour in 1/4 cup of water and cover to steam the potatoes. This will take about 10 minutes. Uncover and stir every few minutes to loosen up the bits on the bottom.
column31: Make the crema by blending the ingredients together. If it's a bit thick add in water a tablespoon at a time until it reaches your desired consistency.
column32: Once the potatoes are soft make little divots in the hash and crack in the eggs. Cover and cook another 3-5 minutes until the whites are set but the yolks are still runny.
column33: To serve top with desired toppings

column9: Salt and freshly ground black pepper
column14: 1/4 cup Mexican crema or sour cream
column16: 3 tablespoons queso fresco or mild feta cheese
column28: Salsa: Combine the tomato, onion, jalapeno, and cilantro in a bowl. Mix well and season with salt and pepper, to taste. Set aside.
column29: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Brush the chicken breast with olive oil and sprinkle generously with salt and pepper, to taste. Put the chicken on a small sheet pan and roast until fully cooked through, about 25 minutes. Remove the chicken from the oven and allow it to cool before shredding.
column30: In a medium shallow skillet heat enough vegetable oil to come half way up the sides of the pan. Shred the chicken into small pieces and put about 2 tablespoons down the center of each corn tortilla. Roll up each tortilla like a cigar and secure them with a toothpick. Fry the tacos until golden brown on all sides, turning once, about 4 minutes total. Remove the toothpicks and cut each taco in half.
column31: To serve: Top with shredded lettuce and freshly made salsa. Drizzle with Mexican crema and sprinkle with crumbled queso fresco.
